description:
Cosmos: The Galaxy Building Card Game is an engine-building / hand management card game for 2-4 players, ages 13+, lasting 15-45+ minutes (depending on player styles). Featuring beautiful space art. Players draw from a common deck and race to create enough celestial objects into their area of space to complete a common goal, which takes the form of a randomly selected Galaxy card. Once the goal is achieved by any player, the player with the most points wins.

Players start with 5 cards and draw 2 cards beginning each turn. Every card in the game is multiple use; play, resource payment or special discard ability. Cards are played from hand by discarding payment but each card a player controls will also generate a resource token during their turn which may be used for playing cards. The more a player controls the more powerful they become thus making it easier to play more cards.

This game is about choices and sacrifice. And with many circumstantial abilities and effects the replay value is very great. There is also a planned expansion in the works.

—description from the designer

Intended for ages 3 and up, in this delicious game, players will travel through Breakfastland, Lunchland, Dinnerland, and Dessertland, down slides made of bacon and through towers of sushi to experience cuisines of various cultures in this flavorful race to delivery!

As a brand that stands for #EveryFlavorWelcome, this game features a wide variety of cuisines, sparking conversation about different cultures and helping customers travel through playing the game.

Be the first player to reach the winner space, and choose dinner to order for everyone. Delivery is just one tap away!

DoorDash's first ever board game.

-description from publisher's website

Don Q. und die unbekannte Yante is an abstract strategy game for two, played on an 8 x 8 grid. Each player owns six pieces at the beginning of the game. The goal is to either reach one of the two designated fields at the opponent's base line without the piece being eliminated in the next turn; or to eliminate all pieces of the opponent.
A piece always moves exactly three orthogonal steps, with turns being allowed. If a piece reaches an opponent's piece's field, it captures that piece. Players can re-introduce captured pieces of the opponent on certain fields on the grid, but these pieces are marked; if they are captured again by their original owner, they are out of the game.

Dinodocus is a card game for 2 to 6 players that plays in 45 minutes, in which players assemble dinosaurs strong enough to resist for long periods of time.

In Dinodocus, players will create and modify dinosaurs using cards depicting dinosaur body parts similar to an identikit. On top of these body parts, the cards also carry dinosaur name syllables and attack and defense values. The syllables creates specific names for each of your dinosaurs, whereas the attack and defense value give strength to your dinosaurs.

During your turn, you first draw dinosaur body part cards, then you create new dinosaurs or modify any dinosaur on the table, and then you feed your dinosaurs. Herbivores will share a limited pool of vegetation tokens, while carnivores will hunt other dinosaurs. Your dinosaurs that couldn't find a food source will go extinct. The longer can survive your dinosaur species, and the more victory points you will get.

During the modification phase, a lot of negotiation, intimidation, pleas, bluff, will appear to convince the current player to modify other players' dinosaurs, not yours!

—description from the designer

Guess who is hiding behind the illustrated clues!
Three amusing illustratiins are shown to all the players. Water drops, a shell, antennae... it’s a snail!
A pasture, some wool, a shepherd...

Which child will be the first to guess that it’s a sheep?

As the newest hires at the local bakery, you have been assigned to work with the hottest selling items - the donuts. Your job is twofold: to arrange the donuts in the display case, and to put together boxes to fulfill customer orders. You’ll also want to make an extra push to sell donuts with sprinkles and coffee, as these can earn you extra cash. Sell your delicious treats better than any of the other employees, and you’ll be walking home with the most money at the end of the day.

In Donut Shop, players will be taking turns placing Donut Tiles in the Display Case, earning points based on how many donuts of the same type are connected. Players then have the opportunity to box groupings of donuts in the Display Case in order to fulfill customer requests from their Order Cards and earn extra money.

Bonuses can also be earned from special orders for coffee donuts with sprinkles. At the end of the game, the player that has earned the most money from their donut placement and order fulfillment wins!

A player’s turn consists of the following actions:
1. Add a Donut Tile to the Display Case
2. Score for donut placement
3. Box donuts (optional)
4. Draw a new Donut Tile and Order Card

Eveden: Next level card game is a two player card game playing on 25 squares arranged in an five by five grid. You are the representative of champion from one of the six region. You earn victory point by defeating enemy card. Normally, you earn victory point equal to the defeated enemy card. You immediately win the game when you earn 10 victory points.

IQ FILES - Pecados is a card ESCAPE ROOM game.

It consists in card escape room where 5-6 character that are met in a room, without knowing each other, they will have to find the Exit, resolving several kind of tests: logical, deduction, jigsaw. but be careful!! they can die while they are trying to find the way out!!

There are more than 90 cards in the adventure.

Each card have also a combination number and you can combine any two cards (objects, characters) and see what happen.

The game mixes several kind of mechanics and keep the players in suspense till the end.

Although you can play alone, it's easier to play with more people to help each other.

Each adventure have a level of difficulty from 1 to 10.

Game take from 90 to 120 minutes and there are 2 ways of playing.

Play with chronometer: you only have 90 minutes to finish.
Play with no chronometer: we really suggest this way as you can enjoy the better what's happening in the adventure .

Adventure 1: LIBERACIÓN Difficulty 4/10

Adventure 2: PECADOS Difficulty 6/10

—description from the publisher

Betelgeuse is an abstract game with a space theme; the 397-space hexagonal board depicts Betelgeuse in the center and six other stars near the corners. Players have a supply of stars in their colors.

On a turn a player rolls two dice and places one star with each them; the number rolled determines how many spaces away the new star must be from a printed star (at the start of the game) or a player's own star (later on).

Getting three of one's own stars adjacent in a triangle destroys opposing stars in a certain radius and prevents further play there.

Each player also has a single black hole which can be placed to cause additional destruction, and there is a neutral comet piece which also destroys things; the comet is moved when a player rolls doubles.

There is an advanced game in which players form "solar systems" by encircling empty spaces or the printed stars.

A relaxing drawing game where you design and layout the best yard on a grid. Combo unique yard features like trampolines, fountains and swimming pools to add to your curb appeal.

For 1-99 players. Plays well over Skype or Zoom. Requires 3 20-sided dice. If you don't have d20's, there's a Yard Builder Dice Roller that you can load in any browser.

—description from the designer

Arma is a chariot racing game where two players alternate “shooting” a wooden disc called a chariot around an oval racetrack. Each player attempts a lap and a half around the entire board without being knocked into the gutter. The first player to successfully complete five of these laps will win the game.

—description from the publisher

Domaniacal is a fast paced, 2-5 player strategy card game. Played with domino cards, players take turns removing cards from their hands and stealing from other players to create a stack of cards. Once the draw pile is out, the player with the largest stack wins!

—description from the designer

Come with us to Wonderland and discover its unique inhabitants. Don't be late!

In live escape rooms, participants are locked in and must manage to leave the room within 60 minutes. UNLOCK! lets you experience this cooperative experience at your home gaming table.

Contained in Unlock!: Heroic Adventures but a German edition was released by itself.

There are a million ways to die in the Arctic, so carefully choose your supplies and read the ice well, and you just might secure the coveted prize of discovering the fabled Northwest Passage.

Lonely Cairn is a solitaire game about finding the Northwest Passage in the mid 1800s. Modelled and based upon the ill-fated Franklin Expedition, players will need to equip their expedition and carefully chose what to take with them into the arctic. They will then sail though a channel of icy locations, facing deadly encounters along the way. They must reach the exit by the end of 8 turns, or face being locked in the ice forever.

—description from the designer

In the trick-taking game Illusions of Prestige, the magician players battle it out on stage with their best tricks, with the winner of a trick receiving points while losers gain support from apprentices and gather props to use for rule-breaking illusions.

The game lasts one or three hands as you prefer. At the start of a hand, shuffle the deck of 54 cards — the standard 52-card deck, plus high and low jokers — then deal 13 cards to each player. (With two players, each player draws two cards, keeps one of them, draws two more cards, keeps one, etc. until each player has 13 cards.)

The lead player of a hand plays a card, and everyone must follow suit if possible; if they can't, they can play any card. The highest card in the suit led wins the trick, and whoever played this card places it to the right of their player sheet.

Every other player looks at the props depicted on the card they played, marks off each prop on their player sheet, then places their card to the left of this sheet. A player sheet has a number of special powers (illusions) listed on it, with 3-5 props underneath each illusion. As soon as you've marked off all the props on an illusion, you can use it, whether now or in the future. What's more, each player who lost the trick takes an apprentice token and places it in their reserve, where they can have up to three tokens. You can add these tokens to cards played in future tricks to increase the value of your played card. Transform a 10 into a Jack, Queen, or King!

At the end of the hand, score points as follows:

• For each card used to win a trick, 5 points.
• For each completed illusion, 3-5 points based on the number of props.
• For each suit, whoever has the most cards of this suit to the left of their player sheet scores 2 points for each card; ties are friendly.

After you've played the proper number of hands, whoever has the highest score wins.

In the solo game of Illusions of Prestige, you deal two hands of 13 cards, look at them both, then keep one of them, shuffling the other one to represent your opponent. When you lead a trick, you flip cards from the opposing deck until you find one of the matching suit. When the opponent leads, you deal two cards and use the higher one. Cycle through discards as needed.

The historic estate of Mansfield Park has fallen into ruin. Franny Bertram, a descendant of some of Jane Austen’s most beloved characters, has turned a few rooms into a bed and breakfast and is trying to restore more of it, but she needs your help to find small antiques she can sell to fund the project.

Search the rooms of the mansion to find the valuable items and collector edition books before a hotel developer makes it up the walkway and inside the house. If she does, she’ll take over the mortgage and tear the mansion down. Then Franny’s dream will be no more. There is a secret passage which could help in the search, but you have to find it first.

You get to make choices in how you conduct your search. The item tiles are scattered throughout the rooms face down, and their location changes each time you play. With a list of what you need, you can roll the dice to move throughout the mansion, picking up items when you find them. Each time you look at an item in a room, whether you collect it or not, you’ll draw an action card which may take you to a different place, and that may change your strategy for your next turn. The action card may help the hotel developer move forward to the front door, and that puts the pressure on you and the other players to complete the search before she makes it inside.

Since you also need to put together a set of collectible books, all of which are piled in the attic, it’s your choice when to go there instead of rolling the dice. And then there is the location to the secret passage. Each player has cards that offer clues, but you’ll need to know who has what to narrow down the possibilities. If you are the first to work out where it is, you’ll be able to move freely throughout the house, but you’ll have to decide if it’s worth it to spend your turn on the search for it, or if your time is better spent in other choices. Players who are familiar with Jane Austen’s books will recognize characters and situations, but no knowledge of them is required to play. It’s all about the search!

—description from the designer

Players use the included tweezers to pick up the different ailment parts. But in this edition, they place them into the holes on Cavity Sam the way they're shown on the Operation card. The timer counts down as players hurry to insert the parts correctly. If they're successful, they keep the card and add up the points at the end of the game. If the timer goes off, all of the pieces pop!

Contents: Game unit, 20 ailment pieces, 21 Operation cards, tweezers and instructions.

Each player gets a game card and rolls two dice each turn. The result is covered with a game token on the game card. If a result is already covered it is only covered a second time, if the result consists of two identical numbers (für instance 4 and 4). On the roll of a 7 one token is removed from every number on the card. If the whole 2nd row is covered, the player uses only 1 die for the rest of the game.

The first player to cover all numbers on his card, wins the game.

Volley and Charge!

These rules are 1 page long.

They are intended for a quick and simple horse and musket game set in the middle of the 18th Century, using 25-30mm model solders.

They are meant for use at conventions or when time is short.

They are cut-to-the-bone version of Steady Bayonets 1756.

The rat’s lair is the first adventure in a series of mini solitaire card games. Each adventure is a stand-alone game that requires you to collect various items to help you defeat the evil Lord Zadorf in the final adventure.

The rat’s lair is a tile placement game where you must venture into the foul smelling, rat infested sewers in search of five artefacts lost long ago in the great floods.

Explore the vast sewer network by connecting stepping stones and search for the five missing artefacts whilst avoiding the killer rats which infuriatingly block your path.

Find torches to help you progress through the pitch black tunnels, poisons to help you avoid the rats, and collect as many artefacts as you can before making your way back to the sewer entry point – easier said than done!

Just making it out of the sewers with your life could be seen as a success, but you are going to need at least one or two artefacts to help you in your quest against the evil Lord Zadorf. Three or four would be preferable and escaping with all five should be your ultimate goal, but may be a step too far!

—description from the designer

A cooperative board game of farming and friendship based on the Stardew Valley video game by Eric Barone. Work together with your fellow farmers to save the Valley from the nefarious JojaMart Corporation! To do this, you'll need to farm, fish, friend and find all kinds of different resources to fulfill your Grandpa's Goals and restore the Community Center. Collect all kinds of items, raise animals, and explore the Mine. Gain powerful upgrades and skills and as the seasons pass see if you're able to protect the magic of Stardew Valley!

The goal of the game is to complete Grandpa's Goals and restore the Community Center, which requires you to gather different types of resources represented by tiles. You have a fixed amount of turns to accomplish this. This is driven by the Season Deck of 20 cards, one of which is drawn each turn to trigger certain events. Cooperatively the players decide each turn where they will focus their individual actions and place their pawn in that part of the Valley. Using their actions, they visit specific locations, trying to gather resources to complete their collective goals. Actions include things like: watering crops, trying to catch fish, rolling dice to explore the mines, and many more. When the Season Deck is exhausted, the game ends.

A Wagering Game for 3 to 6 mostly grown-up Adults.

The game consists of a number of rounds in which players draw tiles, play a dice game and then resolve the results to hopefully increase their money (called "shekels"  and represented by various coloured chips representing various denominations).

The tiles come in two colours and two levels. The beginning, or "Scout", level orange tiles represent which game of four - Read Your Mind; More or Less; None the Same; or Knock Knock is to be played in that round. The beginner blue tiles are "Escapade" tiles, which give the player special powers. The advanced (Sage) tiles introduce more game options and new Escapades.

Each player begins with a set amount of shekels, a player guide which shows each game and the particular rules for that game, and a blue tile. The remaining tiles are placed in the provided pouch. On one's turn, the player draws a tile and resolves the outcome - either play the indicated game (orange tile) or if a special power blue tile is drawn, decide on whether to keep or use that tile. The game continues until there are no more tiles to be drawn from the pouch.

The player with the most value in shekels is declared the winner.

A simple trivia game about the Basque country region Pays Basque, in South-west France and North-west Spain.

As long as a player answer questions she/he can keep rolling the dice.

The winner is the first player to collect 5 city-stages, in any order.

1000 questions in 5 categories:

     History,
     Culture & traditions,
     Science & nature,
     Geography & tourism,
     Sport & contemporary life

In Royal Show Hand, players are ministers of the king, struggling to become the most influence person in the king’s court. But be careful, your king is very sensitive. He will not allow others have more influence than him in his own court.

In the game, players will collect a card pattern like a poker game in front to them, while your king will also form a card pattern in front of him.

At the end of game, the player who has highest pattern rank but lower than king’s pattern rank will win the game. If all players’ pattern rank are higher than king’s pattern rank, the player who has lowest pattern rank will win the game.

This game's basic rule can be played by a standard playing card deck.

-description from designer

Micro Dungeon is a simple and fast-played Card based Solo Dungeon Crawler set in a fantasy world full of Monsters.

In Micro Dungeon the player controls a hero who has to find the way out of the dungeon.

On his way through the modular dungeon he has to face various monsters, find keys to open doors and collect equipment to level up his hero.

But be careful, no part of the dungeon is safe, as dangers lurk everywhere.

Can you find the exit or will the monsters tear you apart first?

-description from designer

Frogs on a Lily Pad provides hours of fun for kids while teaching them their numbers. Who can collect the most frogs? Get it, play it, Enjoy!

How to play:


     Spin the Spinner
     Pick a number card that matches your spin
     Collect Frogs


—description from the back of the box

In Blaze, players try to get rid of their cards, but have to achieve this in an extremely clever and very unusual way. The player whose turn it is plays together with the second next player, which leads to constantly changing alliances. In the end, the player who collects the most feathers wins.

Blaze is designed for at least three players and based on the classic Russian public domain game Durak.

To stay true to the game's origins, Russian artist Nadezhda Mikryukova has illustrated the legendary firebirds and the decorative card frames of Blaze in a classic illustration style.

A board game with an organic chemistry theme, not requiring any chemistry knowledge to play.

Playing is centered around collecting carbon atoms, which act as the currency of the game, collecting molecule cards from different functional groups, building molecules to secure the atoms and receiving test tubes that gives a player different advantages and abilities. The player first to collect six different test tubes is winner.

Carbon atoms can be exchanged for other types of atoms as well as regulating an e-level, which must be kept in certain limits. Every time a player passes the Start square on the board all atoms that are not built into molecules are lost.

In an advanced mode other players molecules can be attacked and destroyed.

-description from designer

What a din! The worms wriggle contentedly in the puddles,
completely oblivious to the chickens, who really aren’t their friends ...
Meanwhile, the foxes chase the chickens — making the dogs bark and the chickens squawk!

AIM OF THE GAME
The first player to collect five cards of one species (e.g., five worms) on the table in front of them wins.

HOW TO PLAY
The youngest player decides whether they want to start or will allow the oldest player to go first.
Play then continues in a clockwise direction. When it is your turn, play either one single card or a pair (i.e., the male and female of one species).
Take as many cards from the draw pile as you need to have three cards in your hand again.
Choose one of the three cards in your hand, then place it either in your farm or in a neighbor’s farm.
Depending on the card you play, the following happens:
If you put a chicken in a farm, the farm’s owner must immediately remove two worms from their farm.
If you put a fox in a farm, the farm’s owner must immediately remove two chickens from their farm.
If you put a dog in a farm, the farm’s owner must immediately remove two foxes from their farm.
Haystacks protect the animal cards that are beneath them in the animal line.
Use the pitchfork to remove one top card of your choice from an animal line in a neighbor’s farm. You may also use the pitchfork to remove a haystack.
Always play the farmer card by placing it on the discard pile. Each player — yourself included — must place up to two unprotected dogs (if available) from their farm on the discard pile.

Ex nihilo is a highly tactical and quite novel stack-fighting game with an emergent checkmate-esque win condition. The novelty of this game lies in its central gimmick: Every move consists in moving a stack. In this sense it is a pure movement game. Yet, the game features both placement and captures.

Rules:
The game is for 2 players and is played with stackable pieces of two colors on a hexagonal arrangement of hexagons (a hexhex board). The board starts out empty. The game is over as soon as one player is unable to make a move. The other player is then the winner.

Movement – overview: 
Stacks move along straight open lines and grow when they move away from the center cell. This game is unusual in allowing movement of stacks containing 0 pieces. It is by growing these that pieces get onto the board in the first place.

Movement – details: 
On your turn, you must move a stack not topped by an enemy piece to an empty cell reachable through an unbroken line of empty cells. By convention, a single piece is considered a stack of size 1 and an empty cell is considered to contain a stack of size 0.

If, after you have moved a stack, it is farther away from the center cell than before it was moved (measured in number of steps), its size is increased by 1 per step further away from the center it now is. This is effected by adding pieces to the top of it from your hand.

You may move a proper part of a stack by splitting it.  That is, if a stack contains several pieces you can choose to only move the top n pieces, given that you do not change their order, for any number n less than the number of pieces in the stack.

You may also move a whole stack, but only on the condition that you move it farther away from the center cell. A consequence is that moving a whole stack always results in its size increasing. Together with the convention that empty cells contain stacks of size 0, this also has the consequence that you can effectively place a new stack on the board by moving a stack of size 0.

Note that nothing special happens to the cell you moved the 0-stack from – it still contains a 0-stack.

Capturing – overview: 
Flanked enemy stacks are captured by being taken hostage for a move. Capturing is obligatory: If a capturing move is available, a capturing move must be made.  The winner will be the player who manages to force their opponent to capture an immovable stack.

Capturing – details: 
If (and only if) the top piece of a stack is of your color, it is said to partake in flanking an enemy stack if (i) this enemy stack is exactly in the middle of a line of otherwise empty cells going from the flanking stack to another one of your stacks, and (ii) all three of these stacks are of the same size.

If, after you have moved a stack, it partakes in flanking one or more enemy stacks, you must immediately move one of these enemy stacks. Except for the obvious difference that you are moving an enemy stack, all normal rules apply to this move. For example: If the captured stack grows (if you move it farther away from the center cell, that is), it grows by the addition of pieces of your color, so situations where this hostage move must itself be a capturing move are possible. Such chaining of captures must continue until you capture a stack that is not in a position to continue the chain. Growing captured stacks is the only way to take ownership of them more permanently.

-description from designer

With Alsa Ludo, rediscover alone, with family or friends, the cultural riches of Alsace, by playing with 160 puzzle cards with detailed statements.

Among the many topics covered; Castles of Alsace & Alsatian Traditions: construction and specificities of many castles, famous people or families, significant events, village festivals, local law, gastronomy, costume, dialect, legends, tourist routes, music...

Object of the game: reach 10 points!

Carbondale is a tile-laying game played with standard playing cards. Players have just moved to the small town of Carbondale, and lay cards in a grid representing the social and business networks they are working to develop. By playing clubs, they can win hearts; by buying spades, they can gain diamonds. The winner is the first to have in their networks three hearts and seven diamonds, or three diamonds and seven hearts. If a card in a player's network is not sufficiently protected, it is vulnerable to take-over by opponents. Players will need skill in tile-laying to advance quickly and safely, and will have to carefully manage their hand to balance cards for offense, defense, and building.

The only equipment required is standard decks of cards.

—description from the designer

These coats and hats are terribly disorganized. Group them by colour to win!

Coats & Hats is a tiny card game packed with coats and hats that need sorting. Match the colour of the items on a rack, while preventing your opponent from doing the same.

Each turn, add a card to the outer edge of the rack; then either use a special ability on a card, or flip your card — there's a hat on the back of each coat. Group three items of the same colour and you score!

—description from the publisher

With just 18 cards and no other components, Toymakers is a full worker placement game; collect resources, construct buildings, make toys, spread joy!

Toymakers uses a resource management mechanism where the card you place your worker on is taken into your hand for resources. The cards double as buildings which provide more resources in a single action, and also can be upgraded to a toy, scoring you points! Time your upgrades correctly; when the last card is drawn from the middle of the table, the game ends!

—description from the publisher

The FRITZO Cube is an innovative and sophisticated game for almost all age groups. Each cube consists of 27 cubes. Each individual cube is unique in its color arrangement. The ingenious thing about it: Depending on the game variant, the dice have to be placed next to each other so that they have to meet different or matching colors in all directions.

Players earn points based on rows and "staircases" and player with the highest score wins.

—description from publisher

Lines of Fixation is an abstract strategy game for 2players, inspired by Lines of Action (LoA). As same as LoA, it also has several game pieces start from a distance, the object to unite own pieces and some move constraints, but unlike LoA, it uses a hexagonal board and stacking mechanics.

GAMEPLAY (overview)
Setup each 9 of 2-height stacks as the diagram above. Light color player goes first, alternate turns taking one move with a stack their control (That is, a stack with your color at the top).

Stacks move a straight line the distance exactly its height, dropping bottom disks exactly one by one for each hex. Dropped disks may capture opponent's stacks and/or merge with own stacks. If your mono-color stack of 3- or more height can make capture, you must do so.

And there are important restrictions; if you do not have the highest stack on a straight line, your stacks on the line cannot make any move along the line. And if both of you and your opponent have the highest stacks of same height on a line, your stacks on the line can move and merge but cannot capture.

The object is to make all stacks you control adjacent each other as a group. You can also win by having two bi-color stacks of 6-height.

-description from designer
Educational game in order to sensitize people about caring for the environment and the different animal and plant species focused on European fauna.

In this game, all players are neighbors in an apartment building. However, living in a crowded block can test your nerves, especially when you have Nasty Neighbors.

After each attack you're unable to prevent, you'll pop a pill to calm your nerves. However, take too many and you're eliminated from the game.

Your goal is to force the other neighbors to leave and be declared "Lord of the Building!"

If a neighbor runs out of pills, their nervous system can't take the stress - they are forced to leave the building.

In the end, there is only one survivor... or NONE!

A dynamic game of strategy, observation, humor, and luck... everything you need to stay sane with bad neighbors.

—description from the designer

"Vietnam: 1965-1975" re-creates the longest, most complex, and least understood conflict in US history in all of its military and political aspects. The rules include detailed treatment of movement, terrain, search and destroy operations, special operations, firepower, airmobility, riverines, brigade-level formations, limited intelligence, and auxiliary units in each scenario."
That's the blurb from the back of the original Victory Games edition of the game.

There are several small scenarios and a couple of campaign games. Each year is divided into four seasons (Spring, Summer, Fall, and Winter), and each season has two turns (so, roughly 6 weeks per turn). The map scale is roughly 6 miles per hex and units are, generally, battalions or regiments. During the operational phase, players take turns (who gets to operate is determined by the NLF player) conducting operations with their units to destroy the enemy, clear the roads, take towns and cities, or just reposition units. In the Campaign Game, during Seasonal Interphases, each player decides whether and how many additional units and/or resources to bring in to the fight. The game features hidden VC units, airmobility, riverines, national morale, pacification, ARVN effectiveness, and many other nuances that allow the player to grasp the some of the experience of what it might have been like to conduct the war in Vietnam.

An updated reimplementation of the Victory Games' classic.
This edition changes some of the rules as well as clarifications. Components are also upgraded from the original printing.
See developers' word.

COMPONENTS

        3 22"x34" maps (approx. 66"x40")
        Rulebook
        Playbook
        2 11"x17" Seasonal Interphase (Population Control Reference, Strategic Bombing, Blockade and Morale Chart/Sheet)
        2 11"x17" Operations Player Aid Card (General Operations, Search & Destroy, Security and Bombardement flowcharts)
        2 CRT/TEC player aid cards
        1 Sequence of Play card
        US, SVN, and NLF Record Sheets (3)
        Population Control Record Sheet
        Allied and NLF Holding Boxes (2)
        4 sheets 9/16" counters
        2 sheets 1/2" counters 


(description from publisher's website and BGG user's comment)

On your mark! Get set! ROW! You are the captain of a sleek, speedy trireme, racing in the famous Hydra Regatta. Steer around whirlpools, shifting currents, and fickle gods. Avoid the hungry hydra to win a place among the stars!

In Greece Lightning, you race around a circular track, trying to be the first to complete two laps. On a turn, you roll two dice to move your boat: a navigation die (1-3) and a movement die (1-6). You can roll a second movement die to try to go farther, but if the roll is lower than your first movement die, you bust and keep only your navigation die.

The circular track is comprised of twelve wedges, with the wedges being randomized each game. In general, the track consists of four paths orbiting the central hydra, but these paths criss-cross a lot, with movement dots and bonus icons at various spots on the movement paths. When you move, you must move clockwise a number of spaces equal to the sum of your dice, but you often have freedom to weave from one path to another. Here are the icons you might encounter:


    Fish: Collect one fish. You can have up to three fish on hand, and you can spend a fish to re-roll your navigation die or second movement die. You might also need fish to navigate whirlpools.
    Favor of the Gods: Draw a favor card, and place it face down before you. At the end of your turn, reveal the card and use it immediately, save it for later, or give it away, depending on what card it is.
    Track wedges: Collect one wedge and place it face up before you. At the start of your next turn, after determining your total movement, place the wedge on the game board (but not on the starting tile or a player's ship). Use these to make your path easier or to place a hydra directly in your opponents' way.
    Whirlpool: When you land on a whirlpool, you often have multiple exit paths from it — but you might need to pay fish or have a die with a certain number in order to take a particular path.
    Hydra: Spend a fish when you land on a hydra space or else your movement will vanish for the rest of the turn as you must fight it off.


When you land on or cross the starting line, thereby finishing one lap, you receive a fish, a wedge, and a Favor of the Gods card. When someone has completed their second lap, you finish the round to ensure everyone has the same number of turns, then whoever has gone the farthest wins.
Trivial Pursuit: Lorraine lets you discover or rediscover the Lorraine region, in North-east France with questions in 6 categories.

You don't want to be stuck with sticks in Stick Stack, so try to place them as carefully as you can on the wobbling tower in the center of the playing area.

Each turn, you either draw a stick from the bag or choose one of the sticks in front of you (in case you had collected any on an earlier turn), then you place that stick onto the tower — but when you place it, the colors on that stack can touch only matching colors on the crow's nest or on other sticks that have already been placed. (If a stick slides onto other colors later as the tower tilts and wobbles, that's okay, but you need to match when placing!)

If any sticks fall off the tower on your turn, collect them and place them in front of you. When all the sticks have been placed onto the tower or when the tower falls over, the game ends immediately. If you caused the tower to fall, you don't collect any of the sticks, but you do score five points (which isn't good). Every player scores one point for each stick in front of them.

If anyone has eleven or more points, the game ends and the player with the lowest score wins.

Stick Stack Cool Black is a new version of the origin Stick Stack game. It provides a cooler color selection and challenge cards element to enhance the game play experience.

Le Mans et son Pays is a local board game based on the principle of questions and answers.

Players start in one of the town centers in the department of Sarthe... and then go travel all the sectors with 550 questions relating to geography, history, celebrities....

The winner will have to be the first one to collect 5 "Site" cards by going to their respective box and answering the question correctly.

This picture book and game tells the story of The Birth of Stone Monkey. In Aolai Country, there is an island called Mountain of Flowers and Fruit which has a magic stone on the top of it. The stone receives the power from nature and bursts open one day to produce a stone monkey. The stone monkey leaps straight to the waterfall to explore and travel across the continents and oceans to worship Patriarch Subhut for learning skills.

Different adventure levels combined mathematical knowledge into the game to help children enlighten thinking, master knowledge, develop good habits of independent learning and active thinking. 6 games correspond to 6 education points: recognize three-dimensional graphics; recognize numbers; understand locations and directions; recognize time, and recognize plane figures and colors. It also includes an observance ability training activity.

To win 6 levels of the game:
- The Birth of the Stone Monkey: Fill the picture that shows the scene of the Mountain
- Jump into the Cave of Water Curtains: Help the monkey jump into the cave of water curtains
- Monkey King in the Cave of the Water Curtains: Help the monkeys host the feast
- Search for Three-Stared Cave: Find Three-Stared Cave
- Pass Down the Magic in the Middle of the Night: Find out the exact time to meet Master Bodhisattva
- 72 Transfigurations: Help Wukong learn three kinds of transfigurations

After you complete each level, insert the manual card to the corresponding page in the passport comes with the game. The first one who collects all 6 manual cards and fills the passport is the winner of the game.

-description from publisher

This game challenges the players to re-fight the Battle for Hamburger Hill. Can you, as the U.S. player, destroy the NVA, capture the hill and deny the enemy their base area? Or will the NVA player triumph and hold their ground? Get ready to re-live or re-write history in the battle for Hamburger Hill!

The Battle for Hamburger Hill lasts 11 turn-pair game-days (with a night turn each game-day also).  Each turn, players alternate moving and attacking each other’s forces on the game map, which is divided into hexes.  Combat can include small arms firefights between adjacent units or fire missions that target hexes with artillery, airstrikes, helicopter gunships and mortars.

At the end of each combat phase, once all fire combat is complete, adjacent units may conduct close quarters combat (CQC) to decide which force will occupy contested hexes.  Each game-day, after all movement and combat is completed, both sides draw cards to determine special actions for the future day’s turns and may get reinforcements according to card events, history and the roll of the dice.

As the North Vietnamese Army (NVA) player, your goal is to hold hill 937 and hill 916.  If, at the end of the last turn, the U.S. player does not control both of the summit hexes, you have won.

As the Allied player, your goal is to control both summit hexes at the same time.  Whenever the U.S. player has accomplished this at the end of a game-day, the game ends with a U.S. victory.

Flip & Phrase is a game that allows children to use Chinese words flexibly, make sentences by association, and makeup stories creatively. In the first half of the game, children do not need to write, so they can focus on their creation. The second half is "writing", using associative memory, writing out keywords, and recreating the scene of the story. In the game, there are 200 frequently used words from the Chinese primary school vocabulary list. The vocabulary list requires children to master the dictation of the words and be proficient in basic Chinese words. Using the form of "oral composition" and "extract keywords", the game lowered the difficulty of the composition and raise the children's learning interest in this subject. The game also makes full use of the means of "listening, speaking, reading, and writing", combined with a real-time feedback mechanism that children can fully use their imagination to break the shackles of thinking and master the skills of composition.

Game setup: Each player takes a player map and its corresponding scoreboard, a pencil, and a sheet of notepaper. Each player draws 5 word cards. Hold them in the hand and don't let other players see them

To start the game: Reverse the hourglass for timekeeping. All players have 30 seconds to prepare an impressive story with the 5 words on the card. After 30 seconds, all players place the cards face down on their map from left to right, starting with the first player and telling each player's story in a clockwise manner. To end the game: When all players have finished telling the story, invert the hourglass and wait 30 seconds, then write down the other players' words in order on a sheet of notepaper. When one player has written all the words can be remembered, place the paper in the center of the table and turn the hourglass around again. The other players have another 30 seconds to continue to recall and record words.

After all players submit their answers, the words will be revealed by the order of storytelling. Players will give their scoring marks to the player who first turned in the notepaper with all words in a correct manner. 1 point for each correct word (correct order and spelling), 2 points for each player who memorizes 5 words from your story, 2 points for each score mark earned from another player, and -2 points for the player's own score mark. The player with the highest total score wins.

—description from the publisher

Come to appreciate the classic Chinese poetry!

Poetry Express contains 75 classic poems that are required to be learned in Chinese primary school. Children can read and appreciate these classic works of "painting in poetry, poetry in painting" through the form of games. In the game, children enjoy the learning experience of poetry with their endless imagination by describing the picture expressed by the poem, knowing the poem, expressing the poem, and imagining the artistic conception of the poem.

Game setup: Shuffle the cards into a deck, use the top card of the deck to form a 5*5 square matrix with the cards face up. Shuffle the question stick, put them into the container and set it at a convenient place, put the hourglass aside

To start the game: Shake the question stick container, randomly draw 2 sticks, show the 4 keywords on both sides of the display to all players. After all of the players have confirmed the keywords, the first play reverse the hourglass, all players find and take the poem cards that meet the requirements from the square mix. Players check each other's poem cards after taking the cards that meet the requirements or after the hourglass's time is over. If a player picks up a poem card that doesn't match any keywords, the player should put all the poem cards taken from this round in front of them with the frontside of the cards facing up. If the poetry cards you take meet more than 1 requirement, for each additional keyword meet the requirement, you can take an additional poetry card from the deck (with the backside facing up, without checking the frontside of the card) as a reward, put all the poems cards and reward cards in front of you with the backside of the card facing up

To end the game: The game ends when there is no more question stick to draw or cannot complete the 5*5 square matrix with the poem cards. Each backside-up poem card counts 1 point, and each two frontside-up poem cards counts -1 point. Less than two frontside-up cards will not count the score. The player with the highest total score is the winner.

-description from publisher

The most desired (limited edition) sneakers are launching soon! Gather your friends to queue up and buy the sneakers! Suit up, warriors. This is War and get as many shoe boxes as possible!

Players are scalpers and play with cards. Players who collect shoeboxes with 20 points will win the game.

There are sneakers cards, queuer cards and action cards. Sneaker card shows the condition to get scores, i.e. the queuer card limit and also the points which can be taken. Queuer cards and action cards are for your hand management.

Random players begin to play clockwise and each player will choose one colour of queuer cards and action cards. They will be divided into 2 card decks. Each player draw 2 queuer cards and 2 action cards.

During your turn, player can play the queuer card concealed and below the sneaker card. If there are already queuer cards present, put below the last queuer card and queue up. Player may also choose to use action cards to fight against others, to increase own queuer numbers or create chaos. Once the queue vacancy of particular sneaker is full, reveal all queuer cards in this row and check the total queuers of each colour. Player can get points in form of shoeboxes and stack them up (There are 72 mini shoeboxes figure). Any player who collects shoeboxes with 20 points will be the winner.

—description from the publisher

Manhattan is a unification game that always ends with one player (the winner) gathering all their pieces in one group.

Rules:
The game is played on a 6x6 square board covered in a checkered pattern of pieces of two colors, except the the 4 central squares are empty. On your turn you have two options: Move or remove. If you cannot do either you automatically pass. (One player will always have a move.)

• Move:
With one of your pieces that is not part of a group, take the first orthogonal step of the shortest possible walk along a clear path that leads to a friendly piece. That is: Of all clear paths to all friendly pieces, you must choose the one that consists of the smallest number of orthogonal steps, and reduce it by 1 orthogonal step.

• Remove:
Remove one of your pieces that belong in a group of same-colored pieces. You may not make a removal that will split the group the removed piece was part of.

In this game, at least four players try to get rid of their hand cards by discarding either the matching color, number or symbol on the discard pile.  But since everyone wants to win, there is of course the possibility of repeatedly putting a spoke in your fellow player's wheel. Action cards can be used to attack them and prevent someone else from playing their last card first.

Up to this point, the principle sounds familiar to many, but in "DOPPELT ODER NICHTS" (German for "DOUBLE OR NOTHING"), some things work a little differently: For example, it is possible to defend yourself by deflecting the attack on a fellow player, who in turn has the same option to defend himself. In this way, it can hit anyone and you can never be sure to reach the goal without being disturbed.

Constant action is therefore the order of the day and does not end with the cards. Those who are willing to take risks can, sometimes under full physical effort, gain an advantage in this card game. Through interactive, cognitive or coordinated tasks it is possible to prevent the drawing of penalty cards. However, one should then think twice, because whoever fails the task receives double the penalty. The deal is: "DOPPELT ODER NICHTS".
